repnme.cdata!: Jordan - Economic Reform and Development Loan

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Economic Reform and Development Loan
            (ERDL) for the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. The broad thrust
            of the reform program is based on the following elements:
            (a) maintaining macroeconomic stability; (b) promoting
            economic integration with world markets, starting with
            exploiting Jordan's proximity to Europe; (c) reforming
            the public sector and creating a sound environment for
            private sector development; and (d) improving the
            functioning of the financial sector to promote more
            efficient mobilization of savings and better investments.
            Bank's performance was satisfactory. Borrower's
            performance was highly satisfactory. The key lessons learned
            were as follows: (i) The ERDL came at a time when the
            government was underway with its reform program, but due to
            exogenous factors, such as the redemption of Jordanian
            Dinars (JD) held in West Bank and Gaza, needed breathing
            space to ensure macroeconomic stability without sacrificing
            the rapid pace of reform.

18231187.majtheme: Public sector governance,Trade and integration,Economic management

repnme.cdata!:
Jordan - Economic Reform and Development
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
A key objective of the Economic Reform
            and Development Loan Project is to support Jordan to address
            the constraints on its long-term growth imposed by the
            limitation of a small domestic market. The project supports
            trade and investment policy reforms to: 1) remove the
            quota-based preferential treatment of goods originating in
            or going to specific countries, or convert it into a
            full-fledged free trade agreement that satisfies the World
            Trade Organization rules; 2) remove import licensing
            requirements; 3) reduce and restructure tariffs, including
            the elimination of the various import fees and surcharges;
            4) remove tariff exemptions; 5) establish a credible path to
            achieving full long-term trade liberalization; 6) equalize
            domestic taxes on imports and domestically produced goods;
            7) establish a business-enabling investment environment and
            strengthen investment incentives; 8) streamline and
            rationalize customs administration; and 9) improve the
            operations of export development schemes.
